bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Henry Hanson, September 5, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] writes that he is recuperating from an angina pectoris attack. He agrees with Hanson's yellow fever strategy. He discusses his current work on the origins of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Henry Hanson, September 5, 1923
div1.opener:
C1
B22
/LC
September 5, 1923.
Dear Doctor Hanson:
div1.p:
Your letter of August 15th. has just reached me here, where I am
in hospital as a result of an attack of angina pectoris, due--it is believed-
to a break down of my cardiac reserve from over exertion. I have been
here for a month, but hope to return to Washington within a week or ten
days as I am allowed to sit up some now in a wheel chair. I expect to
attempt no more field work, however.

I don't know where Puerto Santos is. You evidently place it on
the Magdalena. I know Barranca Bermeja and: Puerto Wilches and everybody
knows Calamar--probably the most disagreeable in South America.

You are absolutely right to give measures to prevent extension
the precedence over those for the elimination of yellow fever. I really
do not know the country well enough to judge of the detail of your work, but
I know that all the people--not only the peones--use the Magdalena for a
great water-way between the north and south and there is no reason to believe
but that the whole country of Colombia in the delta is infectable territory--
that is, infested with aegypti.

I remember Dr. Garcia Medina and liked him, as also I did Dr.
Vengo Edis at Baranquilla. There is no question of the superiority (as a whole
to the Peruvians. They are a much more virile people.
When I get back to Washington, I will write to Mrs. Hanson.

When you finish your work I will be be exceedingly glad to
know what you think of the region of the outbreak--whether the infection,
in what I think we must call the “Maracaibo District” (Bucaramanga: Cucuta:
Encontrado: Maracaibo etc)--I mean all places whose natural port is Mara-
caibo--lasted over from the last epidemic in Bucaramanga--my recollection is

in 1914--to the present time. I do not mean lasting at any one place
that long, but in some place, first one then another, in this general re-
gion.

You know Guiteras found yellow fever in Coto in 1918. There is
much movement in the region I have mentioned and in other parts of Vene-
zuela and Colombia both by trail and boat.

I will still be able to do some work and within three months expect
to send you a section on the Place Origin of Yellow Fever--telling all
that I know or can find out on this subject.

By the way, you can discredit the Norman settlement and exploita-
tion on the West Coast of Africa about 1482. It didn't happen. The legend
is due, I think, to French vanity and based upon their trade with the (so-
called) “Grain Coast” of Africa (between the Great Desert and the Sierra
Leone), begun in 1616. There was no claim made to it until well after
this date.
Wishing and praying for your success, old man, I am

You should get from the Rockefellers the Report about Colombia of the
1916 expedition: Lyster: Whitmore and Wrightson insepcted Bucaramanga and
Cucuta. Also a paper (printed my recollection is) which they have (a re-
port of a Colombian physician) on the last great recognized epidemic in this
section--I mean what I have called the “Maracaibo District.” Both should give
you valuable information.
